title-group.article-title: The Cheilosia canicularis group (Diptera: Syrphidae): species delimitation and evolutionary relationships based on wing geometric morphometrics

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: The Cheilosia canicularis group ( Diptera : Syrphidae ): species delimitation and evolutionary relationships based on wing geometric morphometrics
JASMINA LUDO Š KI 1 , LJUBINKA FRANCUSKI , ANTE VUJI Ć & VESNA MILANKOV
University of Novi Sad , Faculty of Sciences , Department of Biology and Ecology, Trg Dositeja Obradovica 2, 21000 Novi Sad , Serbia . E-mail: 1 jasminal@ib.ns.ac.yu

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: A landmark-based geometric morphometric approach was used to assess differences in the size and shape of wing among/within three species of the Cheilosia canicularis group ( Diptera : Syrphidae ): C. canicularis , C. himantopus and C. orthotricha . Wing size and shape variation was observed from 25, 176 and 41 specimens of C. canicularis , C. himantopus and C. orthotricha , respectively, collected from six localities on the Balkan Peninsula. Significant differences in wing size were obtained among the analysed species and canonical variate analysis showed that wing shape was sufficiently different to allow the correct classification of 73% individuals of C. canicularis , 80% of C. orthotricha and 94% of C. himantopus , and clear delimitation of the species pairs C. canicularis / C. orthotricha and C. himantopus / C. orthotricha . In all analysed species, the consistent sex dimorphism in wing shape was observed indicating that female specimens had shorter and broader wings than males. The UPGMA cluster analysis based on squared Mahalanobis distances revealed close accordance with previously published phylogenetic relationships of these species indicated by allozyme and DNA sequence data analysis. Our results suggested that wing parameters contain useful information in quantification phenotypic variation and identification of species in this challenging group for taxonomy and systematics.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Key words: Cheilosia canicularis , C. himantopus , C. orthotricha , species identification, phenotypic variability, wing geometric morphometrics

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The genus Cheilosia Meigen, 1822 ( Syrphidae , Diptera ) is the largest genus of European hoverflies with more than 175 European species ( ). It is primarily distributed in the Palaearctic, with the highest diversity in the forest habitats, especially in broad-leaved woodlands ( ). This paper focused on Cheilosia canicularis (Panzer) , C. himantopus (Panzer) and C. orthotricha Vujić & Claussen , a group of species belonging to a broadly defined the C. canicularis group that comprises two additional species, C. japonica Herve- Bazin and C. yesonica Matsumura ( Barkalov 2002 ) . The species C. canicularis , C. himantopus and C. orthotricha have throughout Palaearctic distribution, while the other two occur only in Japan ( ).

The taxonomy of the C. canicularis group was a matter of disagreement. The complex relationship between C. canicularis and C. himantopus has generated controversy regarding taxonomic rank. Since it was described in 1801, the C. canicularis species has been known under number of synonyms ( ; ). Taxonomic difficulties in the correct identification of these two species were caused by low levels of phenotypic variation and the great similarity in larval development ( ; Stuke 2000). Due to these, it has been hypothesized that the taxon is one species with two generations ( ) or it is indeed two evolutionary independent units ( ). The nomenclatural status of C. himantopus was recently clarified by based on detailed study of the morphological characters and ecology of both adult and immature specimens. Given the taxonomic dilemma more detailed analyses of biology ( ), morphology ( , 2000; ; ; ) and molecular variation ( ; ) were performed. Beside diagnostic morphological characters of adults (such as length of aristal hairs, specific hypandrium structure and distribution of pilosity on tergits III and IV in females) for identification and separation of species of the C. canicularis group provided by , it was observed that on the Balkan Peninsula female specimens of C. himantopus lack black hairs on the mesonotum, while C. canicularis has intermixed black and yellow hairs ( ). Adults of analysed species of the C. canicularis group are active from early spring to late summer; a flight period of C. orthotricha is from February to July, C. himantopus from April to August and C. canicularis from June to September ( ; ). It has been observed that larvae of both species C. canicularis and C. himantopus develop in petiole tissues and the rhizome of Petasites spp. ( ; ) and that females of C. himantopus ovipositing on leaf bud in late spring, while C. canicularis laid eggs on the leaves in late summer and early autumn ( ). Finally, in spite of very low level of interspecific genetic variability revealed by analyses of molecular markers ( ; ) the boundaries of the genetic units represented by C. canicularis , C. himantopus and C. orthotricha species were well defined based on diagnostic allozyme loci and species-specific mitochondrial COI haplotypes ( ).

However, subtle phenotypic variation at intra- and interpopulation levels of focal species of the C. canicularis group has not been performed. Since geometric morphometrics was confirmed as a powerful tool in taxonomy and systematics of insects (e.g. ; ) and hoverflies ( ; J. Ludoški, unpublished), the usefulness of wing landmarks for delimitation of species of the C. canicularis group was examined. Additionally, studies of wing measurements can lead us better understanding of phenotypic diversity and taxonomy of closely related species of the C. canicularis group. Thus, landmarkbased geometric morphometrics have been used: 1. to identify species of the C. canicularis group based on morphometric parameters (shape and size) of right wing, 2. to quantify intra- and interspecific variation, 3. to analyse sexual dimorphism, and 4. to analyse evolutionary relationships among species of the C. canicularis group.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: Sample collection

Samples of ten populations of the Cheilosia canicularis group species ( C. canicularis 41 specimens , C. himantopus 176 and C. orthotricha 25) for the geometric morphometric analysis were collected from six regions on the Balkan Peninsula : Eastern Alps ( Slovenia , SLO), Jahorina Mt ( Bosnia and Herzegovina , BIH), Fruška gora Mt ( Serbia , FG), Homoljske planine Mt ( Serbia , HPL), Kopaonik Mt ( Serbia , KOP) and Durmitor Mt (Montenegro, DUR) over several years (1984-2001) ( Tab. 1 ; Fig. 1 ). Analysed specimens of C. canicularis were collected during July and August , C. himantopus from April to June and one field trip in August on both Kopaonik Mt and Durmitor Mt , and C. orthotricha from end of March to June. Only several analysed individuals of sympatric populations of C. canicularis and C. himantopus from Kopaonik Mt and Durmitor Mt were collected at the same date (in August ) .
Geometric morphometric analysis

Morphometric analysis was carried out on the right wing of 242 ( 110 males and 132 females ) specimens and each wing was mounted separately in Hoyer’s medium between microscope slides. Wing images were captured using a stereomicroscope Leica MZ12.5 and attached video camera Leica DFC320 connected to a PC computer. Data for wing size and shape were obtained by positioning ten landmarks at vein intersections or terminations on digitized wings using TpsDig software (version 1.40; , freeware at http:// life.bio.sunysb.edu/morph/) ( Fig. 2 ). This program express landmarks as x,y coordinates in Cartesian space.

Wing size was computed as centroid size (the square root of the sum of squared distance between each landmark and the wing centroid), an isometric estimator of size, and then tested for differences among species, populations and sexes by ANOVA. Shape variables were extracted from the landmark data. Briefly, the raw coordinates were first superimposed (aligned, translated, rotated, and scaled to a unit centroid size) using a generalized orthogonal least-squares Procrustes (GPA) procedure ( ). Then, the partial warps representing the non-uniform shape variables and uniform components were calculated. The resulting matrix ( w ; ‘weight matrix’ of ) was used for Canonical variate analysis (CVA) to examine pattern of among-species/populations variation in total shape space and to obtain the classification matrix. Visualization of shape changes associated with canonical axes was achieved through deformations obtained by regression w matrix onto canonical axis scores ( ). The phenetic relationships among spe- cies/populations were determined by UPGMA cluster analysis ( ) on squared Mahalanobis distances.

Both centroid size and w matrix were obtained utilizing TpsRelw software (version 1.44; , freeware at http://life.bio.sunysb.edu/morph/), multiple regressions and visualization of deformation grids were computed with the TpsRegr 1.31 ( , freeware at http://life.bio.sunysb.edu/morph/), and all statistical analyses were calculated using Statistica for Windows (version 7.1).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The ANOVA on centroid size of the wings showed a highly significant difference among species of the C. canicularis group ( F (2,239) = 47.90, p= 0.000; for all pairwise comparisons post hoc Tukey test p <0.001); C. himantopus had the biggest wings, being followed by C. canicularis and C. orthotricha . Also, wing size differed significantly among five conspecific populations of C. himantopus ( F (4,171) = 11.73, p= 0.000) and two of C. canicularis ( F (1,39) = 8.78; p= 0.005), but not among three populations of C. orthotricha ( F (2,22) = 1.90, p= 0.172; post hoc Tukey tests were not significant) ( Fig. 3 ). Tukey's post hoc test revealed that population of C. himantopus from Eastern Alps had significantly smaller wing size than individuals of conspecific populations from Fruška Gora, Homoljske planine and Kopaonik Mts.

Canonical variate analysis (CVA) conducted on the w matrix evidenced that 73% individuals of C. canicularis (11 out of 41 specimens were classified as C. himantopus ), 80% of C. orthotricha (five out of 25 specimens were classified as C. himantopus ) and 94% of C. himantopus ( 11 specimens were misclassified - three as C. orthotricha and eight as C. canicularis ) were correctly classified (overall classification success was 89%) indicating that wing shape has a certain interspecific discrimination power. The two axis extracted by the CVA of w matrix were highly significant and contribute to shape differentiation among species (Wilks’ Λ=0.326, F (32,448) =10.51, p <0.000). The first canonical axes accounting 61.2% of total variation clearly separated C. canicularis and C. orthotricha . The C. himantopus species appeared as an intermediate group and partially overlapped with other analysed species ( Fig. 4 ). The CVA indicated that male specimens of C. canicularis from Durmitor Mt were mixed with C. himantopus males ( Fig. 5A ), while nearly all female specimens of C. canicularis and C. himantopus were separated in two distinct clusters except C. himantopus from Kopaonik Mt ( Fig. 5B ). Based on wing shape, male specimens of C. canicularis and C. himatopus on both localities Kopaonik and Durmitor Mts were clearly different, while females were slightly overlapped ( Figs. 5A, B ).

When sexes were considered separately, intraspecific sexual size dimorphism was detected; male specimens had larger wings than female of C. canicularis ( F (1,39) =0.92, p =0.34) and C. himantopus ( F (1,174) =3.96, p <0.05) contrary to C. orthotricha ( F (1,23) =2.10, p =0.16) ( Fig. 6 ). Sexual dimorphism in shape was highly significant in all analysed species ( C. canicularis : Wilks’ Λ=0.007, F (48,66) =5.88, p <0.000; C. himantopus : Wilks’ Λ=0.025, F (144,1209) =5.01, p <0.000; C. orthotricha : Wilks’ Λ=0.00002, F (80,28) =2.94, p <0.001) ( Fig. 7 ). The CVA provided discrimination between sexes of all three analysed species by the first canonical axis, which accounted for 83.8% of the total shape variation. The thin-plate spline visualizations showed that most of the shape changes were associated with differences in relative positions of landmarks 2, 3, 5 and 6, which influence the wing’s length and width ( Fig. 8 ).

Analysis of interpopulation variation within each species revealed that there were no significant differences in wing shape among conspecific populations of analysed species of the C. canicularis group. The UPGMA cluster analyses of the squared Mahalanobis distances computed from w matrix clustered C. canicularis and C. himantopus in the same branch while C. orthotricha was the most divergent species ( Fig. 9 ).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present study investigated the morphological differentiation pattern among three species of the Cheilosia canicularis group using landmark-based geometric morphometric analysis. We found considerable interspecific differences in wing size and shape. The smallest wings of C. orthotricha had clearly distinct shape from C. canicularis and C. himantopus wings. In comparison with this, canonical variate analysis revealed lower, but also important, phenotypic differentiation between C. canicularis and C. himantopus . Since it has been known that wing shape exhibits a high heritability in nature, as it was reported for Drosophila species and Apis mellifera (e.g. ; ; ), morphological differentiation observed among the taxa of the C. canicularis group indicated that the analysed species have independent evolution. Moreover, observed divergent wing shape phenotypes in sympatric populations from Durmitor and Kopaonik Mts clearly demonstrated C. canicularis and C. himantopus as evolutionary independent entities. Our findings are in general agreement with previously published molecular and genetic studies. Namely, analysis of allozyme nuclear loci provided eight diagnostic loci for delineating C. orthotricha from the other two species, while species-specific alleles at the Est locus differentiated all three species of the C. canicularis group ( ). Similarly, low but consistent molecular differentiation between C. canicularis and C. himantopus was observed in mtDNA COI ( ) and COII ( ) gene sequences. Lower intraspecific variation and modarate but significant interspecific differences in wing shape supporting hypothesis that closely related species C. himantopus and C. canicularis were splited recently (ca. 0.3–0.6 Mya, ).

Geometric morphometric analysis discovered the existence of morphological variation between genders within the species of the C. canicularis group. Substantial male-biased sexual dimorphism in wing size was registered for C. himantopus , although female-biased sexual size dimorphisam is far more common among invertebrates and it was detected for about 80% of investigated species of instects ( ). Significant differences were found between males and females of all three analysed species for wing shape. In shape terms, female wings are shorter and broader than male wings across all three analysed species. It was documented that homologous landmarks tend to have opposite displacement in females and males. For instance, landmarks 2 and 3 were more posterior positioned and landmark 6 was more anterior in female than in male. In females landmark 5 had distal displacement in comparison with more proximal position in males as well ( Fig. 8 ). The consistency of this pattern of dimorphism is also evident in other Cheilosia species (J. Ludoški, unpublished). Wing shape differences between the two sexes might be induced by differences between males and females in reproductive roles, since aerodynamic performance and courtship song in dipteran species are likely to be affected by wing shape ( ). In addition, it has been suggested that gender differences represent a developmental constraint on wing shape in Drosophila melanogaster ( Gilchrist et al . 2000 ) .

The UPGMA dendrogram obtained from wing shape parameters provided evidence of phenetic divergence between the evolutionary distinct species C. orthotricha and closely related species C. canicularis and C. himantopus . Phenetic relationships presented herein were compatible with phylogenetic relationships of populations of the C. canicularis group constructed based on allozyme ( ), and COI mtDNA and nuclear DNA data (28S rRNA gene) ( ). A similarity between phenetic and phylogenetic relationships suggesting that wing shape might be of phylogenetic significance within this species group and that there is an association between the extent of phenotypic evolution and genetic changes.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: This work was supported by the Ministry of Science of Serbia , Grant Number 143006B and the Provincial Secretariat for Science and Technological Development (Maintenance of biodiversity – “Hot spots” on the Balkan and Iberian Peninsula). J. L. and Lj. F. are supported by a PhD fellowship from Ministry of Science of Serbia .
